Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill - Stand.earth
contents.content: Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill - Stand.earth Donate About About Us Our Story Our Approach Financials Staff & Board Job Opportunities Contact Our Work What We Do How We Do It Our Campaigns Get Involved Donate Take Action Join Our Community Insights & Press Research Group Reports & Resources Donate About Us Our Story Our Approach Staff & Board Job Opportunities Financials FAQ Contact Our Work What We Do How We Do It Our Campaigns Research Group Insights & Press Reports & Resources Take Action Donate ©  2004 - 2025 Stand.earth | Privacy Policy | Copyright Policy | Customer service: ChatBot , HelpDesk , KnowledgeBase & LiveChat Website by Studio Lake Press Releases Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill November 19, 2025 OTTAWA | TRADITIONAL, UNCEDED TERRITORY OF THE ALGONQUIN ANISHNAABEG PEOPLE – While governments and civil society meet in Brazil for COP30 to address the climate emergency, Prime Minister Mark Carney and Alberta Premier Danielle Smith are advancing the most controversial fossil fuel project in Canadian history – a dirty tar sands bitumen pipeline from Alberta to the B.C. coast. This financially unsound project, already stopped once , risks First Nations and civil society opposition and international condemnation, and is a complete break with Canadians’ efforts to advance Indigenous Reconciliation and climate commitments. In 2016, after years of Indigenous and civil society opposition and legal challenges, the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline – which would have transported 500,000 barrels of toxic bitumen oil per day – was halted. In 2019, a federal moratorium on oil tankers in coastal waters of B.C. stretching from the northern tip of Vancouver Island to Alaska was enacted in law, affirming the critical value of this region to coastal communities, First Nations, and marine life. An informal moratorium had been in place since 1972. At the UN climate talks in Brazil, over 80 countries are calling for a roadmap to transition away from fossil fuels. And some, from China to Pakistan, are making unprecedented leaps forward in renewable energy generation, particularly solar power. By contrast, Canada is moving in the wrong direction, expanding fossil fuel production, including recently announcing support for two new liquified methane gas (LNG) facilities . Fossil fuels are the single largest driver of human-caused climate change. Liz McDowell, Stand.earth Senior Campaigns Director, said: “Any attempt to build another pipeline to move the dirtiest oil on the planet through one of the most ecologically fragile places on Earth will be met with an opposition that will make the Trans Mountain, Enbridge and Keystone XL protests look like a kid’s birthday party. Every climate and social justice civil society organization on these lands, and beyond, will be tireless and dogged in our resistance. This is not just about Canadian wildfires and droughts, this is about fossil-fueled storms decimating nations like Jamaica and the Philippines, and entire islands sinking due to rising seas. Lawsuits will be filed. Protests will fill the streets and the halls of government. We will mobilize nationally and internationally to rise for legally-protected Indigenous rights.” Regarding Northern Gateway 2.0 , Kiki Wood , Senior Campaigner with Stand.earth said: “Danielle Smith doesn’t seem to understand that ‘no’ means ‘no’. Advancing a dirty tar sands bitumen oil pipeline through sacred temperate rainforest and unceded territory, trampling Indigenous rights while world leaders meet to tackle the climate crisis is a stab in the back, a traitorous offense, a disappearance of leadership, and morally repugnant. The Trans Mountain tar sands oil pipeline cost taxpayers $35 billion and it still isn’t operating at full capacity. With global oil demand projected to tail off, why would we need another pipeline? People living in B.C., including Coastal First Nations, have been clear, we are not willing to risk another Exxon Valdez-sized tanker disaster. Canada has the chance to invest in clean energy and protecting nature, not doubling down on the very fuels driving wildfires, floods, deadly heat and droughts.” Regarding the rolling back the tanker ban, Anna Barford, Oceans Campaigner with Stand.earth, said: “Setting the tanker ban adrift means losing billions of dollars in the ocean economy by exponentially increasing the timeline for the big oil spill. Tankers inevitably have accidents that lead to spills, which are impossible to clean up. Tar sands products are sticky and sink, the impact from a spill will last generations within the ecosystem, which is why the ban was in place to begin with. Removing the decades long protections against a worst case scenario oil spill is an act of designating a sacrifice zone for tar sands prosperity.” Regarding moving ahead with carbon capture and storage technology (CCUS) , Sven Biggs, Oil and Gas Campaign Director with Stand.earth said: “Carbon capture and storage is nothing more than another subsidy for the fossil fuel industry and an excuse to keep burning oil and gas. The federal government has already spent $9.1 billion on it at the behest of the fossil fuel industry only to show that it’s costly, unproven at scale, and to date has captured roughly 0.5% of national emissions. Either way, carbon capture is not a solution to the majority of fossil fuel emissions, which come from burning oil, gas, and coal by the end user.” Liz McDowell, Stand.earth Senior Campaigns Director, added: “In just months Carney has undone a decade of climate progress, dragging Canada back to the Harper years. This shortsighted focus on expanding oil and gas is only going to hurt Canadians. While other countries are making unprecedented leaps in renewable energy production, Canada’s stuck in the past – and we’re going to get left behind.” ###### Contact Liz McDowell, Senior Campaigns Director – Stand.earth +1 604-219-6337, liz@stand.earth (Pacific Time) Sven Biggs, Canadian Oil and Gas Programs Director – Stand.earth +1 778-882-8354, sven@stand.earth (Pacific Time) Richard Brooks, Climate Finance Director – Stand.earth +1 416-573-7209, richard@stand.earth (Eastern Time) Kiki Wood, Senior Oil and Gas Campaigner – Stand.earth +1 604-367-1865, kiki@stand.earth   (Pacific Time) Arin de Hoog, Communications, Oil, Gas and Shipping – Stand.earth. +1 613-978-7329, arin.dehoog@stand.earth (Eastern Time) Latest Insights & Press Shareholder Proposal Seeks Board Committee to Address Wells Fargo’s Indigenous Peoples’ Rights Risks November 20, 2025 Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill November 19, 2025 As COP30 meets in Brazil, 62 faith institutions announce fossil fuel divestment commitments November 18, 2025 View All Share Related More LNG production means more methane emissions, here is how to mitigate that Learn More Stand.earth at the 2025 UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues Learn More LNG tankers become stranded assets as demand collapses, say environmental groups Learn More Our Financials 85% of all our expenses go to our programs Learn More Join the Stand.earth community and raise the bar on climate action Start Here Want to join our community? COMMENTARY: Selected US States Offer Enormous Advantages for AI Data Centers – Yogi Schulz As US Expands NGL Exports, Fractionation Capacity Risk Emerges Exxon to Acquire 40% Stake in Enterprise Bahia NGL Pipeline November 20, 2025 EnergyNow Media Email Facebook Twitter LinkedIn English Español 简体中文 हिन्दी Português These translations are done via Google Translate Print The companies plan to boost capacity to 1 million barrels per day after the deal closes, expected by early 2026, by adding pumping stations and building a 92-mile extension to Exxon Mobil’s Cowboy gas processing plant in Eddy County, New Mexico. The 550-mile Bahia line, now in commissioning, is set to start commercial service soon, moving 600,000 bpd of mixed NGLs from the Midland and Delaware basins to Enterprise’s Mont Belvieu fractionation hub in Texas. With natural gas liquids output climbing in the Permian, the Exxon Mobil tie-up and New Mexico extension put Bahia in a stronger position to move those fuels to market. “As the ratio of natural gas and NGL production to crude continues to increase in the Permian, the Bahia pipeline will be an essential artery,” Enterprise co-CEO Jim Teague said, adding that NGL output in the region is expected to grow more than 30% from 2024 to 2030. The extension, which will also connect to several Enterprise-operated plants in the Delaware Basin, is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2027. Exxon Mobil’s portion of the project will be called the Cowboy Connector, while Enterprise will operate the combined system. (From Paradigm Press) (Ad) Northstar Financial Companies Inc. Reduces Holdings in Exxon Mobil Corporation $XOM Written by MarketBeat November 21, 2025 Share Link copied to clipboard. Image from MarketBeat Media, LLC. Key Points Northstar Financial cut its stake in Exxon Mobil by 44.4% in Q2, selling 4,318 shares and leaving it with 5,415 shares worth about $584,000 per its latest 13F filing. Exxon raised its quarterly dividend to $1.03 (up from $0.99), representing a $4.12 annualized payout and a ~ 3.5% yield ; the record date is Nov. 14 and the payment date is Dec. 10. Analysts rate Exxon on average a "Moderate Buy" with an average price target of $128.67 , while the stock trades near $117 with a market cap of about $493.6B and a P/E of ~ 16.6 . MarketBeat previews top five stocks to own in December . Northstar Financial Companies Inc. decreased its position in shares of Exxon Mobil Corporation ( NYSE:XOM - Free Report ) by 44.4% during the second quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. The fund owned 5,415 shares of the oil and gas company's stock after selling 4,318 shares during the period. Northstar Financial Companies Inc.'s holdings in Exxon Mobil were worth $584,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. 3 Energy Giants Amp Up Dividends—Here’s What It Means for Investors Other institutional investors have also recently made changes to their positions in the company. Eagle Capital Management LLC raised its holdings in shares of Exxon Mobil by 15.3% in the first quarter. Eagle Capital Management LLC now owns 2,836 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $337,000 after buying an additional 376 shares during the period. Brucke Financial Inc. boosted its holdings in Exxon Mobil by 2.1% during the 1st quarter. Brucke Financial Inc. now owns 6,792 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $808,000 after acquiring an additional 142 shares during the period. GW&K Investment Management LLC grew its position in Exxon Mobil by 11.6% in the 1st quarter. GW&K Investment Management LLC now owns 3,797 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $452,000 after acquiring an additional 395 shares during the last quarter. United Bank increased its stake in Exxon Mobil by 6.7% in the first quarter. United Bank now owns 21,221 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $2,524,000 after purchasing an additional 1,333 shares during the period. Finally, Wakefield Asset Management LLLP bought a new stake in shares of Exxon Mobil during the first quarter worth $301,000. Institutional investors own 61.80% of the company's stock. Get Exxon Mobil alerts: Sign Up Exxon Mobil Trading Down 0.3% XOM opened at $117.04 on Friday. The company has a current ratio of 1.25, a quick ratio of 0.88 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.12. The firm has a market cap of $493.57 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 16.62, a PEG ratio of 2.06 and a beta of 0.49. Exxon Mobil Corporation has a 12 month low of $97.80 and a 12 month high of $123.21. The stock has a fifty day moving average price of $114.59 and a 200-day moving average price of $110.95. (From Porter & Company) (Ad) Entropy Technologies LP Takes Position in Exxon Mobil Corporation $XOM Written by MarketBeat November 21, 2025 Share Link copied to clipboard. Image from MarketBeat Media, LLC. Key Points Entropy Technologies LP opened a new position in Exxon Mobil in Q2, acquiring 46,291 shares valued at about $4.99 million. Exxon raised its quarterly dividend to $1.03 per share (annualized $4.12) for a ~3.5% yield, with an ex-dividend date of Nov 14 and payment on Dec 10. Analysts have a consensus rating of Moderate Buy and a consensus target of $128.67, with 2 Strong Buy, 8 Buy and 10 Hold ratings and several firms recently raising targets. Five stocks to consider instead of Exxon Mobil . Entropy Technologies LP acquired a new position in shares of Exxon Mobil Corporation ( NYSE:XOM - Free Report ) in the 2nd quarter, according to its most recent filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. The fund acquired 46,291 shares of the oil and gas company's stock, valued at approximately $4,990,000. 3 Energy Giants Amp Up Dividends—Here’s What It Means for Investors Other large investors have also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. Eagle Capital Management LLC raised its position in shares of Exxon Mobil by 15.3% during the 1st quarter. Eagle Capital Management LLC now owns 2,836 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $337,000 after buying an additional 376 shares in the last quarter. Brucke Financial Inc. increased its stake in shares of Exxon Mobil by 2.1% during the first quarter. Brucke Financial Inc. now owns 6,792 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $808,000 after acquiring an additional 142 shares during the period. GW&K Investment Management LLC increased its stake in shares of Exxon Mobil by 11.6% during the first quarter. GW&K Investment Management LLC now owns 3,797 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $452,000 after acquiring an additional 395 shares during the period. United Bank raised its holdings in Exxon Mobil by 6.7% during the first quarter. United Bank now owns 21,221 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $2,524,000 after purchasing an additional 1,333 shares in the last quarter. Finally, Wakefield Asset Management LLLP acquired a new stake in Exxon Mobil in the first quarter worth approximately $301,000. 61.80% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. Get Exxon Mobil alerts: Sign Up Analyst Ratings Changes A number of analysts have recently commented on the company. Wall Street Zen raised Exxon Mobil from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Saturday, September 13th. Piper Sandler lifted their target price on Exxon Mobil from $141.00 to $144.00 and gave the stock an "overweight" rating in a report on Monday, November 10th. Morgan Stanley boosted their price target on shares of Exxon Mobil from $134.00 to $135.00 and gave the stock an "overweight" rating in a research report on Monday, August 4th. Wells Fargo & Company initiated coverage on shares of Exxon Mobil in a report on Friday, October 17th. They issued an "overweight" rating and a $156.00 price target for the company. Finally, Scotiabank reaffirmed an "outperform" rating on shares of Exxon Mobil in a research note on Monday, November 3rd.
